title: 115_hr1957
content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Key findings are outlined in the Act. Congress finds that bullying and harassment in schools can seriously harm students' physical and psychological health, leading to academic underachievement and high dropout rates. These behaviors include physical violence, name-calling, intimidation, and cyberbullying. Schools with anti-bullying policies have higher reporting levels and teacher involvement. Students are targeted for bullying based on race, gender, disability, and other factors. Some experience relational aggression, damaging relationships and social acceptance. Anti-bullying policies in schools lead to increased reporting and teacher intervention, reducing incidents. Interventions like Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS) can help minimize bullying in schools. 85% of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying. Students, parents, educators, and policymakers are calling for action to address the national crisis of bullying. The Safe Schools Improvement Act aims to address bullying and harassment in public elementary and secondary schools by implementing anti-bullying policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires states receiving grants to mandate local educational agencies to establish policies preventing severe, persistent, or pervasive bullying and harassment that limits a student's participation or creates a hostile environment based on actual or perceived characteristics. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates local educational agencies to establish policies prohibiting bullying and harassment based on various characteristics, including race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, and other defining traits. Annual notices must be provided to students, parents, and educational professionals outlining the prohibited conduct. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires local educational agencies to establish policies prohibiting bullying and harassment based on various characteristics. They must provide annual notices describing the prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints. Additionally, they are required to collect data on incidents related to the prohibited conduct. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates local educational agencies to establish policies prohibiting bullying and harassment. They must collect accurate data on incidents and publicly report it while ensuring victims' confidentiality. Additionally, they should promote positive disciplinary approaches to minimize student removal from instruction and prevent disproportionate punishment. State reports are required from the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant under this title, in collaboration with the State educational agency. The report should include information from local educational agencies on bullying and harassment policies, as well as the State's plans to support these efforts. The Secretary is mandated to conduct a biennial evaluation of anti-bullying programs in schools, assess their effectiveness, and report findings to the President and Congress. Data collection on prohibited conduct is required, and the impact of these policies on reducing bullying incidents will be analyzed. The part states that federal and state nondiscrimination laws remain valid and do not limit victims' rights under other laws. It also clarifies that free speech laws are not affected by this part. The text introduces a rule of construction stating that states and local entities can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with the part. It also includes a table of contents for the Safe Schools Improvement section of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
